p: Welcome to the 😈 EVIL BIRD FREE SHIT 😈 mirror/wiki.
Everything from the Discord server is going to be mirrored from here. This page will serve as a backup, and will try to keep constantly updated.
Use the links below to navigate to whatever it is you may need, or you may also use the nav bar on the top.
This is the ultimate Arch install guide for installing, setting up, and optimizing Arch Linux.
Windows VM With GPU Passthrough Setup
This will guide you into installing Arch Linux onto your system, and how to set it up. This guide is heavily based on the original Arch Installation Guide.
This guide will also assume that you have downloaded, flashed, and booted into the Arch Linux Live USB.
It is recommended you test inside a VM before proceeding on a real machine in order to make sure what you are doing.

l: Verifying you are in UEFI mode
p: If you are booted from the live USB, verify it's in UEFI mode by listing the efivars directory:

If the directory does not exist, then the USB is not booted in UEFI mode. Make sure to boot it into UEFI mode before proceeding, or continue if you what you are doing, as this guide assumes you are on UEFI.
Use timedatectl to ensure that the system clock is accurate:

Arch should come pre-installed with Ethernet drivers in the kernel, so connecting your computer to the router should be as simple as plugging in the cable. If you are still unable to connect to the network, follow this guide to check the drivers and load modules.

Connecting to the internet can be a hassle in Arch, however assuming that the kernel drivers are loaded correctly, the live USB already comes with tools that make connecting to the internet easy. One such tool, which we are going to use, is called iwd.
If prompted, input the password for the network
If there is no driver loaded, then install the necessary driver by following this guide, or if you have a Broadcom card, continue reading.
If using a Broadcom card, you can load the broadcom-wl driver that is already on the live USB. To load it, we must block the conflicting drivers that are trying to grab the card.
Next, list your available network adapters:
Note down the the WiFi adapter that you are going to be using as we are going to use it for the following commands.
Then, list all of the available networks it scanned:
Tip: If the output is way too long that it goes off screen, try piping it to less in order to go line by line: lspci -k | less, press q to quit.
To block, assuming you are in UEFI mode, edit the kernel parameters to add the following:
To start, launch the iwd shell:

Verify that a kernel driver is loaded for the WiFi card by checking the output of lspci -k for a PCI(e) network card or lsusb -v for a USB card. It should say that a kernel driver is in use, for example:
WiFi is a bit more complicated. You have to set up drivers, connect to the router, and set a DHCP thing or something.
You can initiate a scan for available networks by doing:
You can use systemd-boot to accomplish this by pressing E to edit the kernel boot parameters before booting into Arch.

You need to set up internet before going forward with this guide. Steps are going to be different depending on whether you are going to be connecting with Ethernet or WiFi. You can follow the in-depth guide from the Arch Wiki here, otherwise, here is a summarized/easy-to-follow version:

Now that we are connected to the network, we gotta setup DHCP to access the internet. This is required for both ethernet and WiFi. We are going to be using a tool called dhclient(8) in the live USB, and dhcpcd on the installation (which we will cover later on) to accomplish this.
You can test if your internet is set up correctly by pinging a server:
Add the multilib repository to Arch by editting and uncommenting the [multilib] section:
Add the newly created user to the wheel group:
After doing this, look at the output of vainfo to make sure everything is fine. Lines ending in VAEntrypointVLD or VAEntrypointEncSlice indicate success
After installing, it's as easy as starting and enabling the dhcpcd.service daemon:

After that is done you may want to install some other basic tools before chroot'ing to the install. This can include a text editor or other utilities as the base package doesn't provide all utilities. You can install other tools later with the pacman command, but for now, install the essential stuff like a text editor:
and if everything is setup correctly, Plasma should start and ready to use!
Any other packages you may need, such as WiFi drivers, etc

Auto clean packages- Only keep 1 version after every action yay -S pacman-contrib sudo mkdir /etc/pacman.d/hooks curl -LR https://pastebin.com/raw/WCm35wZC /etc/pacman.d/hooks/clean_package_cache.hook
Before shutting down the live USB, make sure to unmount the drives in case of any error
Before we run the installer, we must install python and the actual installer, archinstall, itself:
Being logged in as root all the time is dangerous and not recommended, therefore, we must create a new user without root privaleges.
Bluetooth: sudo sed -i 's|#AutoEnable=false|AutoEnable=true|g' /etc/bluetooth/main.conf sudo systemctl enable --now bluetooth.service
By default, Arch does not have audio configured. To setup audio, install pulseaudio and alsa-utils:
cd into the repository and finally, run mkpkg:
Change the root password by using passwd(1):
Check for any busy errors after each command. If all goes well, you can finally shutdown the system and boot into Arch!
Check the resulting file in case of any error:
Check the VA-API acceleration state at about:support page, look at HARDWARE_VIDEO_DECODING row. If there's available by default, you're running on hardware by default
Choose "Assign mount-point for a partition" > select parition 0 (boot is True) > type /boot
Choose "Assign mount-point for a partition" > select your ext4 partition > type /
Choose "Mark/Unmark a parition to be be formatted" and choose your empty linux partition
Choose "Set a desired filesystem for a partition", and use ext4
Click the "Transparency" tab and adjust the slider
Click the Configure button. Set Noise strength to 0 and adjust the Blur strength slider
Connect to the network the same as before in the Internet section.
Create the .xinitrc file in ~/.xinitrc and add the following lines:
Create this file and fill it in as below sudo gedit /etc/udev/rules.d/60-ioschedulers.rules
Decrease RAM swappiness: sudo sysctl -w vm.swappiness = 10
dhcpcd- A DHCP and DHCPv6 client
Disk layout > "Wipe all selected..." > ext4 > no (no separate partition for /home)
Don't mess this up. Trust me it's gonna save a lot of headaches later.
Earlyoom- Automatically free and manage RAM, and prevent OS freezing: sudo pacman -S earlyoom sudo systemctl enable --now earlyoom
Edit /boot/loader/entries/arch.conf so that the first initrd line is the following: initrd /amd-ucode.img
Edit /boot/loader/entries/arch.conf so that the first initrd line is the following: initrd /intel-ucode.img
Enable colors in pacman: sudo sed -i 's|#Color|Color|g' /etc/pacman.conf
Ensure Breeze is selected and click "Configure"
Example using Central US Chicago time:
Finally, before we boot, we have to install a boot loader and install CPU microcode:
Finally, install any browsers, text editors, file managers, terminal emulators, etc. that you may need. Some examples include dolphin, firefox, konsole, and kate.
Finally, mount the necessary partitions so we can work with them:
Finally, regenerate the locale by running
Finally, you can exit out of the shell by just typing in exit, and it should put you right back into the live USB shell.
Find the VA-API package corresponding to the drivers you chose in archinstall: https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Hardware_video_acceleration#Installation
First, list your disks by using fdisk -l | grep Disk /dev/. It should output all the disks that are connecting to the system, for example:
Fix "too many files" error in Visual Studio Code: echo fs.inotify.max_user_watches=524288 | sudo tee /etc/sysctl.d/40-max-user-watches.conf sudo sysctl --system
Fixes blurry icons in Electron programs: sudo pacman -S libappindicator-gtk3
Fixes for GTK3 menus: sudo pacman -S appmenu-gtk-module
Fixes various issues in KDE apps: sudo pacman -S packagekit-qt5
For HDD rotating disks: ACTION==add|change, KERNEL==sd[a-z], ATTR{queue/rotational}==1, ATTR{queue/scheduler}=bfq
For more information on setting up audio, see this page.
For SSD and eMMC: ACTION==add|change, KERNEL==sd[a-z]|mmcblk[0-9]*, ATTR{queue/rotational}==0, ATTR{queue/scheduler}=bfq
Force the KDE file picker in GTK apps:
Format the EFI partition if you are not dual-booting:
FSearch- Everything Search equivalent for linux: fsearch https://github.com/cboxdoerfer/fsearch
Gamemode- On demand performance optimization: https://github.com/FeralInteractive/gamemode sudo pacman -S gamemode systemctl --user enable gamemoded systemctl --user start gamemoded
Go back to settings > Workspace > Desktop behavior > Desktop effects > Blur
Go to about:config page and set media.ffmpeg.vaapi.enabled to true
GOverlay- OpenGL gaming overlay, similar to MSI Afterburner's overlay: goverlay https://github.com/benjamimgois/goverlay
Handler for file picker portals: sudo pacman -S xdg-desktop-portal
Heroic Launcher- Launcher for GOG and Epic Games: https://heroicgameslauncher.com/
I would do this after you are finished with the live USB, before booting into Arch for the first time.

If once you have booted the Arch install and you might have some packages missing, you can boot back into the Arch live USB and chroot back into the system. Just remount the root partition as we did in the partitioning section and run the arch-chroot command like we did in the setting up section.
If the output says root then it's set up.
If you are using Grub bootloader: sudo grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg
If you decide to be sane and use UTC on Linux, then you must do the same on Windows.
In Windows make sure you created a new empty partiton. Use diskmgmt
Install libva-utils: sudo pacman -S libva-utils libva-vdpau-driver
Install missing fonts: sudo pacman -S noto-fonts noto-fonts-cjk ttf-dejavu ttf-liberation ttf-opensans
Install the base, linux, and linux-firmware packages to the root partition:
Install the dependencies base-devel and git:

Installing manually is recommended, as it teaches you how the system works and is recommended by the Arch Linux developers. However, you may choose to use the archinstall tool if you do not feel comfortable doing so. Proceed at your own risk.
Instead of following the same instructions as in the Setting up DHCP section, we are gonna use dhcdcp do setup DHCP.
Intel (2014 and newer): sudo pacman -S libva-media-driver
It is recommended to create a swap partiton. If you do choose to create one, create a swap partition starting at 300MiB and end it at whatever size you choose how big your swap partition is:

It is recommended to have Windows installed before you continue with installing Arch. While booted into Windows, open Disk Management, and resize your main data partition to make space for Arch, and optionally, a swap partition. Afterwards, continue to Formatting.
It is recommened to use UTC time if you are dual-booting multiple OS's as it causes less issues than using either exclusively localtime or mix and matching.
iwd- Tool we used earlier for WiFi

Limit journal files to 2 weeks: sudo journalctl --vacuum-time=2weeks

Sysctl network optimizations: sudo sysctl -w net.core.netdev_max_backlog = 16384 sudo sysctl -w net.core.somaxconn = 8192 sudo sysctl -w net.core.rmem_default = 1048576 sudo sysctl -w net.core.rmem_max = 16777216 sudo sysctl -w net.core.wmem_default = 1048576 sudo sysctl -w net.core.wmem_max = 16777216 sudo sysctl -w net.core.optmem_max = 65536 sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.tcp_rmem = 4096 1048576 2097152 sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.tcp_wmem = 4096 65536 16777216 sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.udp_rmem_min = 8192 sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.udp_wmem_min = 8192 sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.tcp_fastopen = 3 sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.tcp_max_syn_backlog = 8192 sudo sysctl -w net.ipv4.tcp_max_tw_buckets = 2000000
System Monitor- KDE task manager: plasma-systemmonitor
The hostname is basically the PC name, and is used to uniquely identify the device on the network. See RFC-1178 for choosing a hostname. Examples could be arch-pc, arch, gaming-pc, etc.

Packages listed like this are the package names. They can be installed with pacman.
Packages with aur come from the AUR. They can be installed with yay or another AUR package manager.
Packages with git does not have a package on any repository (afaik). Installation instructions can be found on the GitHub page of the package, which is linked.
pamac-aur-git aur: Manjaro's Arch software center
ufw and gufw: A Linux firewall, activate by doing sudo systemctl enable --now ufw
fsearch aur: Everything Search equivalent for Linux
kdenlive-git aur or kdenlive-appimage aur: Video editor
mpv: Open source and cross platform video player
User Scripts: Scripts that add functionality to mpv
lutris: Game manager and Windows emulator
proton aur: Compatibility layer for Windows game on Steam
Note: Valve recommends you use proton that is shipped with the Steam client itself, only use this package as a fallback
heroic-games-launcher-bin aur: Launcher for GOG and Epic Games
playonlinux: UI wrapper for Wine to run Windows programs
goverlay-bin aur: OpenGL gaming overlay, similar to MSI Afterburner's overlay

There are some cases where using the WINE emulator for Linux or Proton or other Windows compatibility layers for Linux may not work for the program you are trying to use. In this case, create a Windows virtual machine is your next best option to run these Windows programs, however the performance of a virtual machine can be spotty, and at times, bad, compared to running it on bare metal. The main issue with them is video acceleration. One way to solve this, however, is passing through your entire GPU to your virtual machine, giving you almost bare-metal performance.
This guide will be heavily referenced from the offical Arch Linux guide, thus if you need more information or troubleshooting, check out the guide.
A CPU that supports hardware virtualization and IOMMU.
Host GPU will be the one outputting Linux
One or more monitors for your host GPU
One or more monitors for your guest GPU
A spare keyboard and mouse is recommended to passthrough to the VM

It is possible to do this with one GPU (it has to be dedicated) by unloading the video driver before the virtual machine starts, and loading the VFIO driver, and doing some more steps. Searching around could lead you to a guide on how to do this.
You could exclude the monitor requirement for the host GPU if doing this purely via the command line with SSH, which will not be covered here. The same could said with keyboard and mouse.
💰 For all services you need a paid account unless the service has a free tier (will rip but in lower quality) !

🎧 🚫 Dolby Atmos now also has a new codec called AC4 (AC-4 IMS/Dolby AC-4 with Dolby Atmos immersive stereo), found on most services that also have e-ac3. AC4 cannot be played in any player, currently.
🎧 🚫 360 Audio cannot be played in any player, currently.
🎧 Other: Dolby Atmos (e-ac3 JOC 768kbps 48kHz and/or AC-4 IMS), 360 Audio (MPEG-3D mha1 and/or mhm1 48khz 600kbps - 1700kbps) & Spatial Audio (variant of Atmos or 360 Audio, not the same as Apple)
Amazon Music Unlimited must be available in your region for more than SD. Example: India up to SD.
Difference between Amazon Music Prime and Amazon Music Unlimited
🎧 Others: Dolby Atmos (e-ac3 JOC 768kbps 48kHz) & Spatial Audio (Apple proprietary rendered AAC binaural mix)
Private for higher than AAC (Lossless, Hi-Res and Atmos)
Spatial Audio not possible to rip, for now.

📀 Purchasing: various lossy and lossless formats
Purchasing quality tracks cannot be ripped!
Bugs also has 📀 24 bit FLAC but it's only for purchasing, cannot be ripped!
KKBox Japan has up to High only, aka 💽 320kbps AAC.

l: NetEase Cloud Music, Lizhi, QQMusic, Yiting, Kuwo, Kugou, Qianqian, Migu, JOOX, Fivesing & Ximalaya
p: All: from ::floppy_disk: MP3 128kbps to 📀 FLAC 24 bit 192kHz
Others (QQMusic only): 🎧 Dolby Atmos (e-ac3 JOC 768kbps 48kHz and/or AC-4 IMS) & 360 Audio (MPEG-3D mha1 and/or mhm1 48khz 600kbps - 1700kbps)
Every song/album uploaded after May 2020 is watermarked and fake upscaled from 16 bit to 24 bit (lossy noise conversion to be undetectable).
Most Chinese streaming platforms share the same versions from NetEase meaning most should have these watermaked songs/albums.
💩 Master: MQA (lossy) encoded FLAC up to 24-bit 96kHz
🎧 Others: Dolby Atmos (e-ac3 JOC 768kbps 48kHz and/or AC-4 IMS) & 360 Audio (MPEG-3D mha1 and/or mhm1 48khz 600kbps - 1700kbps)

WARNING about Tidal's Master. 💩 MASTER tag is NOT a indication a album is hi-res! MASTER is a lossy encoding that is also present on regular 16 bit 44.1kHz (example: Wu-Tang's Enter the Wu-Tang 36 Chambers). As a result, please check your files using a spectral program (like Spek).

Discord Client Setup: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VivIVnIQMq4, My Amoled Theme: https://pastebin.com/sHRnTSBp
HeadsetControl- Replacement for Logitech G Hub: https://github.com/Sapd/HeadsetControl
LockHunter- Delete files in use by another program: https://lockhunter.com/
mitmproxy- Intercept system traffic (bonus: use Proxifier): https://mitmproxy.org/
Notables are 7-Zip, Revo Uninstaller, Notepad++, Everything, Windirstat, ShareX
OpenHashTab- File Hash and VT Scan Checker: https://github.com/namazso/OpenHashTab
Sandboxie-Plus- Safely run untrusted software: https://sandboxie-plus.com/downloads/, Crack: https://pastebin.com/YWXdxDDL
Wireshark- Low level packet inspection: https://www.wireshark.org/
x64dbg- Step by step assembly debugging: https://x64dbg.com/
YT-DLP: https://github.com/yt-dlp/yt-dlp or choco install yt-dlp
Go to about:preferences#librewolf, disable "Enforce OCSP hard-fail"
Search for network.dns.disablePrefetchFromHTTPS and set it to false
Search for network.predictor.enable-prefetch and set it to true
uBlock Origin- Adblock (preinstalled on LibreWolf): https://ublockorigin.com/
ClearUrls- Remove tracking from urls: https://docs.clearurls.xyz/
I Still Don't Care About Cookies- Hide cookie concent popups: https://istilldontcareaboutcookies.com/
SponsorBlock- Skip youtube sponsors: https://sponsor.ajay.app/, go to interface > disable "show buttons on youtube player"
Dark Reader- Everything in dark mode: https://darkreader.org/
Survol- Preview links on hover, like in Safari: https://survol.me/
TWP- Translate web pages in real time: https://github.com/FilipePS/Traduzir-paginas-web
Nimbus- High quality browser screenshot/screen recordings (Firefox has this): https://nimbusweb.me/screenshot/
Violentmonkey- Userscript support (search "Userscripts I Use" for guide): https://violentmonkey.github.io/
HLS Downloader- Any video downloader (not YouTube! use https://upull.me/): https://github.com/puemos/hls-downloader
Jumpcutter- Skip video/audio silence in real time: https://github.com/WofWca/jumpcutter
Substital- Add subtitles to any video: https://substital.com/
Enhancer for YouTube- Better YouTube UI: https://www.mrfdev.com/enhancer-for-youtube

l: 🚀 Free Lifetime 200GB VPS, 4x CPU cores, 24GB Memory 🚀
p: Requires a valid credit or debit card to create an Oracle account. BINs or virtual cards will not work.
Guide by cevoj35548. Based off this tutorial.
Go to the Oracle Free Tier page.

Scroll down under What are Always Free cloud services? and check the resources included in the always free offer: Arm-based Ampere A1 cores and 24 GB of memory usable as 1 VM or up to 4 VMs with 3,000 OCPU hours and 18,000 GB hours per month.
Press the Start for Free button and complete the registration process. You can create a fake identity and disposable email, but the registration will require a credit card to complete.
You will be taken to a webpage with a purple banner indicating that you are on the free plan. Unless you specifically upgrade to a paid account, you will not be charged.
Under Launch Resources, select the Create a VM instance option. Give the instance a name.
Move down tho the Image and Shape box, and click Edit. Click Change Image and select the checkbox by Canonical Ubuntu. Set the OS version to 20.04. Then click the blue Select image button.

Scroll down and click Change shape. Change the Shape series to Ampere. Scroll down and check the VM.Standard.AI.Flex default size, and increase the Number of OCPUs slider to 4. A yellow Service limits status warning will appear, but you can proceed by pressing the blue Select shape button.

Scroll down to Add SSH keys, and select Paste public keys. Download and install PuTTY, and open an application called PuTTYgen(PuTTY Key Generator). Click Generate and paste the Public key into the website's SSH keys input field.

Scroll down to Boot volume and click Specify a custom boot volume size. Set the Boot volume size (GB) input field to 200. A yellow Service limits status warning will appear again, but you can proceed by pressing the Create button at the bottom.

You may see a red banner, Out of capacity for shape VM.Standard.A1.Flex in availability domain. If this happens, scroll back up to the Placement box and click Edit. Click a different Avaliability domain and try to click Create again.
Your server will now start provisioning. Return to PuTTY Key Generator and click Save private key; you will be using it to connect to the server via SSH. Save it to any file location.
For SSH setup ONLY, skip to Step 14.

Now that the server has finished provisioning, you need to allow RDP connections on port 3389. Under Primary VNIC click your Subnet. Then, under Security Lists, click the Default Security List for vcn-.... Click Add Ingress Rules. This should now open a modal for Ingress Rule 1.

In the Source CIDR field, type 0.0.0.0/0. In the Destination Port Range - Optional field, type 3389. In the Description field, type RDP. Then, click Add Ingress Rules. You should now return to the Security List page. In your browser, click back twice to return to your instance dashboard.
Under the Host Name (or IP address) field, enter the Private IP address of your instance. This can be found under Primary VNIC in your instance dashboard.

In the Category tree in PuTTY, navigate under Connection> SSH and click Auth, and click the Browse button under Private key file for authentication and select the .ppk file you saved earlier in PuTTYgen. Now scroll back up to Session in the Category tree. Enter a name under Saved Sessions and click Save. Now click Open. You may recieve a PuTTY Security Alert warning; click Accept.
Oracle will reclaim your VM if your CPU, RAM, and Network usage is below 10%. To avoid this, please run the script below within a tmux session:
Stop here if you want to use this server for terminal only. You can now connect to your VPS with PuTTY. Use tmux to keep programs running after closing SSH.
To use it as a portable desktop ( install a DE), please continue:
In the PuTTY window, enter the following commands. Click (enter) on popups when nessecary.
Type: sudo passwd ubuntu, and enter a new password for your RDP connection. Now type sudo reboot.

Open Remote Desktop Connection in Windows. Click Show Options. In the Computer field, enter the Private IP address of your instance. In the User name field, enter ubuntu. Check the Allow me to save credentials box.
Go to the Local Resources tab. Under Local devices and resources, ensure only Clipboard is checked, and Printers is unchecked.

Click Connect. You may get a The identity of the remote computer cannot be verified warning. Check Don't ask me again and click Yes. A Windows Security window will pop up. Enter the password you created earlier and click OK. You will now be in the Ubuntu desktop.

If you are using GNOME( ubuntu-desktop), open Settings, Privacy > Screen Lock, and change Blank Screen Delay to Never, disable Automatic Screen Lock, disable Lock Screen on Suspend, and disable Show Notifications on Lock Screen.
If you are using KDE( kubuntu-desktop), open System Settings, search Screen Locking, and and uncheck the boxes by Lock screen automatically.
To optimize RDP, open a terminal window and paste the following commands:
Change the number of colors that XRDP has to transmit:

If your RDP is still slow: return to the Remote Desktop Connection Windows client, and go to the Experience tab. Set dropdown under Choose your connection speed to optimize performance to LAN (10Mbits or higher).
Open Stacer to prove the CPU Cores (4), Memory (23.4 GiB), and Disk size (193.6 GiB).
You can now access your VPS from anywhere in the world using Remote Desktop Connection. You can optionally set up X11 Forwarding by following the tutorial here.
To monitor the performance of the Ubuntu instance, you can use a graphical performance monitor like Stacer, which will show you the number of CPUs, amount of memory, and disk storage available.
